g.text: strategies of parasite species and how phenotypic plasticity in life history traits determines parasite
performance.
In this study, we explore life history trait evolution in parasitic eyebrights (
Euphrasia
Orobanchaceae).
Euphrasia
represents an ideal study system for investigating the recent evolution of
parasite life history strategies. These taxa are hemiparasites that are photosynthetically competent and
can complete their lifecycle without a host, but grow much better after attachment to one of many
suitable hosts. In the United Kingdom, the 21
Euphrasia
species demonstrate recent postglacial
divergence with many species indistinguishable at DNA barcoding loci [13], presenting similar and
overlapping morphological variation [14, 15], and found to readily hybridise [16]. Despite this
shallow species divergence,
Euphrasia
demonstrates substantial ecological divergence, with many
taxa restricted to specific habitats such as coastal turf, mountain scree or open grassland. This
ecological diversity would be expected to exert strong selection on aspects of the life history of a
generalist parasitic annual plant species such as
Euphrasia
. This may include selection on growth to
match seasonal water availability and to exploit local hosts, or selection on flowering time in response
to local competition.
In our experiments, we first assess the extent of life history trait variation among
Euphrasia
species
and their hybrids when grown on a single host in standardised growing conditions. This experiment
addresses whether there is life history trait divergence among recently diverged parasite species. We
then inspect plasticity of a single focal
Euphrasia
population grown on many different hosts. This
experiment tests whether they are truly generalists by growing them on a wide range of hosts, and also
includes a treatment without a host to observe the phenotype when free-living. Finally, we relate our
trait observations made in a common garden to recordings made on herbarium specimens collected in
the wild. This comparison will help us understand whether life history trait differences hold in both
the common garden and in nature. Overall, our joint observations of phenotypic variation between
closely related species, and the extent of host-induced plasticity within species, both in an experiment
and in the wild, provides new insights into life history variation in parasitic taxa.
